channel.name: Using Proxy contracts and other ways to compile large contracts

messages.content:
The purpose of this post is to describe the method of creating large contracts that can be compiled using the current version of o1js.

Comments, additions, suggestions, and critiques are much appreciated.

## Problem definition:

At the current state of o1js, there is a limitation on the contract size that can be compiled without errors.
If the contract has more than ten methods, there is a high probability of compiling or proving to be failed with one of the following errors:
```
RangeError: offset is out of bounds
TypeError: The encoded data was not valid for encoding utf-8
```
In case several contracts reference each other, this limit is applied to the total number of methods; therefore, if each contract has more than three methods and the total number of contracts is 3, we can encounter those errors.

Given that the DeFi applications can have dozens and even hundreds of functions (take UNISWAP Protocol, for example), we need the possibility to create quite large contracts without facing errors at compile time.

### Compilation

Every Implementation contract can be compiled independently, it does not require the compilation of Proxy or State contracts.

State contracts require the compilation of the small Proxy ZKProgram contract that generates the Merkle Tree proof, this requirement will go away in case o1js will make possible verification with verification keys only, without the requirement to have prover keys.

Proxy contract does not require the compilation of State or Implementation contracts.

### Multicall

Every update of the state requires 2 transactions:
First, the Implementation contract @method should be called that does business logic and creates a new state
Second, the State contract @method update is being called that copies the new state from the temporary Implementation contract state to the permanent State contract state.
I do not see the possibility now to build one transaction with those two steps, and any comments on this possibility are highly appreciated.

### Fees

For example, we have 1 Proxy, 1 State, and 3 Implementation contracts. To deploy those 5 contracts for 1 MINA, the current account creation fee should be lowered from 1 MINA to 0.1 MINA

### Implementation details

In a real-life Proxy implementation, there should be additional logic that locks the state, prevents race conditions, guarantees state integrity ecc.
After receiving feedback on Proxy contracts, I plan to implement this logic in my MinaNFT project.

I’d like to thank @maht0rz and @gregor  who answered my numerous questions when I was trying to find a solution how to compile my large contract.

messages.content:
# Summary - proposed solutions

### Immediately available solution: use Proxy contracts

### Short-term (1-2 months) solution - changes to o1js library:

- make possible verification with verification keys only, without the requirement to have the prover keys
- dynamic loading and off-loading of the prover keys
- using native rust binary
- consider lowering account creation fees from 1 MINA to 0.1 MINA

### Long-term (6 months) - changes to o1js library:

- Move o1js from 32-bit to 64-bit, or
- Separate 32-bit spaces for different contracts

@DFST you can aleviate all of your state management concerns if you migrate your business logic to https://protokit.dev 🤯, however we're still dependant on o1js exposing access to the native prover for the sequencer to be able to prove all the required circuits

embeds.title: Protokit
embeds.description: Protokit enables developers to build zero-knowledge, interoperable and privacy preserving application chains with a minimal learning curve.

messages.content: you also should be wary of concurrency issues, especially if your transactions operate with preconditions - since you work with trees
I plan to join your workshop tomorrow to explore this opportunity further!
Understand this, plan to solve it on the AWS level
why bother writing your own infra? we wrote the entire prover orchestration already
if not protokit, you'd have to write a smart contract that uses sequence state, and then a custom recursive zk-rollup circuit to process merkle tree updates and your business logic
but at the same time you're using new L1 accounts for every NFT (if i remember correctly)
looks like quite a bit of overkill tbh
